head.title: For Mentally Ill, Care, Not Prison

hedline.hl1: For Mentally Ill, Care, Not Prison

abstract.p: Letter from Robert N Davison, executive director of Mental Health Assn of Essex County, NJ, comments on August 20 editorial criticizing wrongful imprisonment of Kerry Sanders, who has history of mental health problems; says situation underscores poor treatment of mentally ill across US

block.p: The wrongful imprisonment of Kerry Sanders, a man with a history of mental health problems, has implications beyond his tragic personal loss of freedom and dignity and the obvious folly of the criminal justice system (editorial, Aug. 20). It is a statement about how our country treats many of its most vulnerable citizens: the seriously mentally ill.

The wrongful imprisonment of Kerry Sanders, a man with a history of mental health problems, has implications beyond his tragic personal loss of freedom and dignity and the obvious folly of the criminal justice system (editorial, Aug. 20). It is a statement about how our country treats many of its most vulnerable citizens: the seriously mentally ill.

More than 265,000 of the country's mentally ill are now in prison, while only 70,000 receive hospital-based care in public facilities. The correctional system has become the biggest psychiatric hospital in the world.

People who suffer from mental illness deserve the community-based treatment they were promised, as well as clean, modern hospitals, when needed. The misfortune of Kerry Sanders should serve notice on the public mental health and criminal justice systems.
ROBERT N. DAVISON Executive Director, Mental Health Association of Essex County Montclair, N.J., Aug. 20, 2000
